title: On a dare from dad, boy wears hot dog suit for 4th-grade photo. The image went viral
text:
A fourth-grade boy who wasn't quite sure what to wear for school photos took his dad up on a bet – and the resulting photo has caught the attention of thousands on social media.

Jake Arsenault's mom, Kari, suggested the 9-year-old wear an old Halloween costume: A hot dog.

Jake wasn't sold on his mom's idea at first. That's according to Jake's father, Craig Arsenault, who spoke to USA TODAY on Saturday.

“Dude, do it ... it’ll be legendary,” Arsenault says he encouraged. He remembers promising his son $10 if he went through with wearing the costume to the Biddeford Intermediate School photo day about three weeks ago in Maine.

Parenting: Little girl hilariously ‘shocked’ when her dad explains how sausages are made

Jake's parents didn't want to stand in the way if their son actually wanted to wear the costume. They even signed a parental letter to the school, asking that Jake be allowed to wear it. The note, written by Kari, said, "We are aware and OK with Jacob Arsenault's intention to wear his hot dog costume for school pictures, if possible."

Jake Arsenault's Biddeford Intermediate School ID shows him posing in a hot dog costume — the result of a bet with his dad. (Photo: Photo courtesy Craig Arsenault)

"Please let this happen!" Craig Arsenault wrote.

This week, Jake's school ID card came – complete with the hot dog suit photo.

Arsenault took a photo of the card Thursday and posted it to his professional Facebook page, which he uses for his work at a U.S. Army recruiter.

"The school let him do it, and I couldn't be happier," the caption says. Arsenault says he often mixes professional and some personal posts on this public page.

Since Thursday, the post has attracted tens of thousands of shares. But as of Saturday, Arsenault still hadn't fully made good on his side of the bet: He's only given Jake $7 in spare cash – he still owes his son $3.

Screen time: How to handle your children's smartphone, tablet and video game addictions

Craig said Jake also posed for a photo in regular clothing, and that photo was used on another copy of Jake's school ID.

While Arsenault said he has gotten some pushback from people concerned for Jake's safety who were worried about his decision to put his son's ID card on the internet, he told USA TODAY in a written statement and phone interview that such critics are living in fear and he is confident his son is safe.

As for Jake, Arsenault says his son loves the attention and is wowed by the national interest, but he does have one regret looking back. The day the photos were taken was only a half day of school – now he wishes he was able to wear the hot dog costume for a full day.
